div1.p: Frost inquires about sections preceding Carter's manuscript.

div1.head: Letter from Wade Hampton Frost to Henry Rose Carter, November 18, 1924
div1.opener:
Book
Frost
THE JOHNS HOPKINS UNIVERSITY
SCHOOL OF HYGIENE AND PUBLIC HEALTH
310-312 WEST MONUMENT STREET
BALTIMORE, MD. November 18, 1924.
DEPARTMENT OF EPIDEMIOLOGY
Dr. Henry R. Carter,
2122 California Street,
Washington, D.C.
Dear Doctor Carter:
div1.p:
Your letter and manuscript were both
received yesterday, but as it happened to be a busy
day with a dinner engagement in the evening, I
have not had a chance more than glance at the manu-
script.

I think it would help me in my under-
standing of your discussion if you would let me
know in barest outline what precedes it in your book.
I ask this because in running over the manuscript
it strikes me that a good deal of knowledge is pre-
supposed - knowledge as to the clinical character-
istics of yellow fever and its essential epidemio-
logy, also perhaps a good deal of knowledge as to
the habits of the vector, its geographical distri-
bution, the geography of Central and South America,
etc. Most of these considerations, except the
geographic ones, which I can readily look up, are
already sufficiently familiar to me, so that I have
no difficulty in following your narative and argu-
ment, but without knowing what precedes this sec-
tion in your book I do not fully understand just what
background the reader, previously unfamiliar with
yellow fever, would have when he arrived at this
point.

Please do not trouble yourself to answer
this query in any detail but if you will give me just
the barest sketch in a few lines of what precedes
and follows this section - merely section headings
or chapter titles - it will help to orient me.

I trust that Miss Laura is having a good
rest at Shirley and that you are taking good care
of yourself in her absence. I have not had a
chance to get to Washington for more than a month,
I think not since your return from your trip, but
I hope to come over within the next few weeks, and
if it is possible to do so, I want to come up and
see you.
With best regards from Susan and myself,
div1.closer: Very sincerely yours, W. H. Frost WHF:G
